Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: There is a queue of product families that are sequentially released on each new process. The Ivy Bridge desktop was the first product released on 22nm. Historically, the Atom was one of the last product families to migrate to the new process. Intel could change the order and move the Atom/SoC products up the process line. What effect would giving the low power smartphone/tablet products a pass to the front of the line have on the 2 year cycle? Cut it in half?

Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: "What effect would giving the low power smartphone/tablet products a pass to the front of the line have on the 2 year cycle? Cut it in half?" I don't think it's as simple as that. There's a reason why low power is at 32nm and the rest at 22nm -- Intel has not optimized the production of specific chips at low power below 32nm. It takes time to do this. Even if you prioritize low power first, you have to face the learning curve of going to a new process generation with a new chip architecture. The volumes involved are so high, there are so many possible variations in the process at fine resolutions that you have to optimize for everything. At low power, they would be doing that for the first time below 32nm. It not a simple mix and match exercise that would cut production time in half because you re-prioritized your targets.

Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: "Even if does give an advantage, Intel can't prevent someone else from following it." *** Yeah, all these things Intel does are easy. All the competitors have to do is follow. Gee, except it takes them three years on average to figure out how to do it and they still don't do it as well. It doesn't matter if what Intel does has a catchy name. It matters if it works and if it produces superior products. Yes to both. The process generation you refer to as long is the shortest in the industry. No one else can match Intel's every eight quarter fabrication cycle. No one even comes close. You continue to throw up criticism that only demonstrates your ignorance about fabrication. I don't know - maybe you're a Wall Street analyst...

Topic.Title: Tick-Tock: The Intel Party Doesn't Stop

Message.Msg: Intel has said on a number of occasions that that is what they are doing and it will cut the time in half. Read up... "The move to Tri-Gate Transistors delivers roughly twice the improvement in transistor performance over conventional planar scaling when applied to low-power applications like smartphones and Ultrabooks. We combine our process technology, manufacturing and design to produce a highly leveraged business model that is becoming increasingly rare in our industry. That model allows us to do things others can't, like advancing our Atom roadmap at twice the rate of Moore's Law through 2014." http://seekingalpha.com/article/505221-intel-s-ceo-discusses-q1-2012-results-earnings-call-transcript

Message.Title: Intel's Next Major Catalyst: IDF
Message.Msg: "Technology Insight: Intel Next Generation Microarchitecture Code Name Haswell" According to the description, this session will give nitty-gritty details on how this next generation CPU will offer "significant improvements in performance and energy consumption, as well as supporting additional enhancements for graphics and support for powerful new instructions". This is particularly exciting, as this first that even on the same 22nm "tri-gate" manufacturing process, the company will manage to meaningfully improve performance and power efficiency. According to Anandtech: "Internally [to Intel] Haswell is viewed as the solution to the ARM (ARMH) problem. Build a chip that can deliver extremely low idle power, to the point where you can't tell the difference between an ARM tablet running in standby and one with a Haswell inside. At the same time give it the performance we've come to expect from Intel" The implications here are fairly dramatic: if Intel is successful, not only do traditional notebooks, as well as "ultrabooks", see significant performance and battery life improvements (spurring upgrades), but this could very well give Intel a huge competitive advantage in the high end tablet segment (for example, the Surface Pro from Microsoft (MSFT) ). That's not to mention that a high performance, even more power efficient CPU core will bring about dramatic performance and power efficiency improvements in higher performance desktops, workstations and servers. http://seekingalpha.com/article/828241-intel-s-next-major-catalyst-the-intel-developer-forum

Topic.Title: Intel's Next Major Catalyst: IDF

Message.Msg: Idle power is so yesterday. The future lies in dynamic power reduction. All day battery life on web browsing work-loads comes from this. That's also where your arhcitecture kicks in. When you have a lot of gates in your design, it becomes harder to bring this down.

I think Intel's suffers from an over-confidence in its process prowess when actually that's what's slowing them down.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 RT Version is Better Than The Windows 8 Pro Version

Message.Msg: Windows 8 RT is simply another nearly non-existent ecosystem going up against two ecosystems each with hundreds of thousands of apps. The catch-22 is that nobody will buy it without apps,and developers won't build apps without customers. The big apps like Facebook, Angry Birds and IHeartRadio will come on fairly quickly for RT. The more obscure ones that have barely made it to Android such as banking and DVR management won't show up in RT. I know this sounds like it wouldn't be bad, but anybody who has ever used an Android tablet knows the feeling of seeing a much needed app that is only available for iPad. Multiply this times a thousand and that will be the experience. "I can't wait to get rid of my iPad for a Windows 8 RT tablet" said no high school student ever.

Message.Title: Apple/Samsung/Intel
Message.Msg: Sure hope that Apple has another foundry source for those "A" chips that are essential to the iPhone, iPad, iPod and a few other products that make up about 80% of apple's revenue. If they are stuck with Samsung Austin, one could imagine that Samsung could mysteriously have a terrible yield problem and the "A" chip flow could turn into a trickle. Is Apple dumb enough to fire this commercial ICBM (lawsuit) at Samsung without having another supplier lined up? I don't think so. Think Intel. FYI, Paul Ottelini in NOT scheduled to speak at the Intel Developer Forum Sep 11-13. I can't find where that has ever happened before. Also remember that the rumored introduction date for the iPhone 5 is Sep 12. Just maybe an Ottelini appearance at the Apple announcement trumps his speech at the IDF. We've seen it before on the change from Power PC chip to x86 back in 2006. Ottelini was on-stage with Steve Jobs for that little announcement. Key question: If Intel is announced as the new Apple "A" chip supplier, does the Intel stock add $10 or $20 on the very next day of trading?

Intel has been three years ahead of the competition in fabrication for quite some time now. With FinFET that's moving up to four years. ARM isn't going to be capable of 14nm, FinFET, EUV or 450mm for years and years. They are struggling mightily with 28nm volume production and we won't see them do volume on 20nm for years. Topic.Title: Windows 8 RT Version is Better Than The Windows 8 Pro Version

Message.Msg: I've been enjoying watching the RT get downgraded by Microsoft over the past couple of years. You were certain that it would be the death of Intel and ARM would be running native Windows programs. As one of your posts from Nvidia put it "Game over." But not only are there no legacy apps Microsoft seems to want this product all to itself. And you wonder why I am skeptical? Now you're saying that ARM64 is going to be the great savior of ARM. Next year Intel cranks up the 22nm production and will head directly to that wonderful ARM 95% market share in the smartphone world. You are the one who keeps coming on this board trying to paint the illusion that ARMH is in control of the future. Last year the "Whole world" invested in ARM and next year the "Whole World" will start to invest in Intel. Consumers buy products for what they can do oblivious to the electronics inside. If they transition from ARM to Intel most of the world won't know or care. If I were you I would be a bit more concerned than you claim to be. You are talking about one competitor who controls the entire design and manufacturing process, plus has money to spend on marketing it's products. Intel isn't a company that can often knock out the competition in the first round, but they have the stamina and tenacity to go round after round, each time getting smarter and fighting harder. Decentralized design, manufacturing and marketing among many companies means a diluted revenue stream to compete against Intel. You say it comes down to design, I say it comes down to money. We'll find out soon enough who is right.

Message.Title: Letter to Goldman Sachs
Message.Msg: Mr. Lloyd C. Blankfein, CEO The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. 200 West Street 29th Floor New York, NY 10282 Dear Mr. Blankfein, It is with great dismay that I have watched Goldman Sachs engage in what appears to be a continuous campaign to negatively impact the stock price of one of America’s great businesses and success stories – Intel. Goldman Sachs, through its analyst James Covello, has expressed excessively negative opinions regarding Intel’s operations and results and enough downgrades to fill a bushel basket. This has occurred not just for a period of weeks or months but literally for a period of years. Mr. Covello appears not only to understand little about fabrication and the chip sector – he appears to have little or no learning curve. He not only has been wrong about Intel, he has been consistently wrong. When it becomes clear that he has been wrong, instead of correcting his views, he simply doubles down. This horrid record in regard to judging and predicting Intel’s performance leads one to question the internal machinations within Goldman Sachs. Are there no corrective actions within Goldman for an analyst with excessively bad judgment that continues for years? For if there are then there has to be another reason for Goldman’s constantly bearish opinions and reports to the press. There are only a couple of possibilities. My great fear is that Goldman’s opinions on Intel have nothing to do with Intel’s fundamentals or results – that Goldman’s opinions on Intel are related to some trading strategy. A phrase for this type of behavior would be "greed at the expense of ethics." Of course I have no way to know exactly why Goldman consistently bashes one of America’s great companies, one of America’s great success stories and a company that manufactures here at home. At a very difficult economic time it would seem that Goldman would attempt to assist in an economic recovery. It appears to me that Goldman is engaging in activities that are as a minimum ethically distasteful and that additionally work against US economic recovery. A review of Intel’s PE ratio clearly demonstrates that the company has been valued far below that of an average S&P 500 while producing substantially better results. It appears to me that Goldman has had a significant role in this valuation with its constant negative views, downgrades and press releases. It also appears to me that Goldman’s efforts in regards to Intel are being mirrored by a number of other key Wall Street firms. I don’t know why anyone with access to information would attempt to present such a biased viewpoint for this extended period of time. I therefore request that you conduct a full investigation of Goldman’s trading, analyzing and reporting activities in regards to Intel. And that you report back to Intel shareholders exactly why Goldman has supported market views of Intel that are not substantiated by facts or actual performance. Until such time as you do, I will ask others to make this same request of you. And I will encourage everyone I know to stop doing business with Goldman until said report is issued. Intel shareholders and investors have had enough of this behavior. We want explanations. Sincerely,

Message.Title: Petascale Supercomputer Under Development in Russia
Message.Msg: Not much has been revealed regarding the specifics of the system, but Shabanov noted that energy efficiency is a key feature of the upcoming super and will employ a “unique cooling system” as well as and cutting-edge x86 coprocessors. The suggests the machine will rely on Xeon Phi (MIC) chips, Intel’s manycore acceleratore that is expected to debut before the end of the year. CPU and interconnect details weren’t revealed. http://www.hpcwire.com/hpcwire/2012-08-24/petascale_supercomputer_under_development_in_russia.html
